Lo!  where triumphant o'er the wreck of years</br>The time-worn FABRICK lifts its awful form:</br>Scath'd with the blast its sculptur'd front appears,</br>Yet frowns defiance on the impetuous storm.</br>What Pow'rs — to more than giant bulk ally'd,</br>Thy firm-compacted mass conspir'd to raise!</br>Then bade thee stand secure to latest days,</br>Wonder of after times, — of CESTRIA'S sires the pride.

Avail not now to make their Founder known</br>Those walls — with hieroglyphic marks imprest,</br>That speak some record in each mouldering stone,</br>To awake conjecture in the pensive breast.</br>For ah!  what Artist in thy form aspires</br>To exist immortal in the rolls of Fame;</br>What mystic moral was the Sculptor's aim;</br>Lost in oblivious maze — in vain the Muse inquires.

So vain is Pride — so faithless to her trust</br>Fame's boastful clarion — that with bold emprize</br>Would eternize the Monarch's sleeping dust,</br>Or give to Ambition's hopes what TIME denies:</br>He envies Genius too his well-earn'd praise,</br>By Truth consign'd to Memory's brazen page;</br>Cancels the scroll with all-corroding age,</br>And prompts the faithless gloss, that Fiction's hand betrays,

While thus around thy batter'd precincts dwell</br>Oblivion's shades, and hovering damps impure,</br>How shall my Muse the invidious charm dispel,</br>Or trace the MONASTERY'S bounds obscure.</br>Yet — venerable Mansion!  long the seat</br>Of Superstition gaunt, and harrowing Fear!</br>I — solitary — love to linger here,—</br>And in thy cloister'd haunts indulge the calm retreat.

Oft through thy spacious aisles I love to stray,</br>Where Heaven's translucent splendours stream no more</br>Through rainbow-tinted pants; — with bright display</br>Though blaz'd each crystall'd arch in days of yore;</br>Or seek thy Choir — the graver's art to trace</br>In carvings richly wrought, or sculptur'd shrines;</br>Or secret Hall of conclave — that combines</br>With Symmetry's chaste form each lighter gothick grace.

And — as on dangerous enterprise intent,</br>Oft from these cheerful scenes my steps I bend,</br>To explore the time-clos'd Crypt's obscure descent,</br>Or mark where Ruins scarce their fall suspend;</br>And less enamour'd of the effulgence bright,</br>That gilds the aspiring Temple's visto'd walls,—</br>To tread on fragments where the reptile crawls,</br>And spy what age conceals, — forego the garish light.

Midst cheerless days — in this sequester'd cell</br>Where never pierc'd the mist-dispelling beam,</br>Some ANCHORET perchance, his beads would tell,</br>Or musing, contemplate the taper's gleam.</br>I mark his pallid form, — his frenzied air;</br>Fell discontent sits brooding on his brow:</br>He starts!  in solitude to curse the vow</br>That tore him from his kind, — and doom'd him to despair.

Lost to the dearest charities of life,</br>Some VESTAL wasted here her blooming years;</br>Sigh'd o'er the names of mother and of wife,</br>And pour'd in secret unavailing tears</br>Absorb'd — a clay-cold form — in silent woe,</br>She sits unconscious, — till the vesper bell</br>Wafts on her startled ear its solemn knell,</br>And wakes her perjur'd lips to ill-dissembled show.

Yet shuddering Fancy starts, as here she strays</br>Near humid Vaults, impervious to the view,</br>Where labyrinthine tracks, and devious ways</br>Confirm the tale, — and speak Tradition true;</br>That hence, — conductive to the distant Fane,</br>Winds the lone passage, — intricate and drear,</br>Dark — subterranean haunt!  where haggard Fear</br>Conceals from days remote his undiscover'd reign.

Here — many a postern in the dim recess,</br>Still yawns suspicious on the aching sight;—</br>While sinuous gulphs above — the foot repress,</br>And wind to depths profound their downward flight:</br>Nor — Stranger!  trust the air-suspended stone,</br>Nor brave the steep, — by fond inquiry led,—</br>Lest ruin'd heaps betray thy incautious tread,</br>And hurl thee headlong down to mysteries unknown.

Yet — once perchance, through those recluse abodes,</br>Sequester'd Melancholy lov'd to stray:</br>Infuriate Treason — that in secret broods;</br>Or Avarice — that shuns the hated day:</br>There Guilt — that seeks in darkest shade to hide</br>His baleful head; — there secret Lust retir'd:</br>Or Murder — with mistaken haste inspir'd,</br>In vain the asylum sought, by Conscience still deny'd.

For Innocence — no devious covert needs</br>Whilst ill-Intent affects the shades of night,</br>She gives to public view her brighter deeds,</br>And gains new lustre from the cheerful light.</br>To wayward Men a living Precept given,</br>Her fair example with instruction teems;</br>Till emulous, they hail its useful beams,</br>And bless the friendly ray, that guides their feet to heaven.

Thus — sang a youthful MINSTREL: — when the Pile</br>No longer echoed to the Vesper song,</br>And pealing Organ; — but each desart aisle</br>Rang to his startling footsteps, lone and long.</br>Now Twilight dimly glimmering hastes to pour</br>Athwart the western Arch his chequer'd ray;</br>Yet still — the unwary Boy prolongs his stay;</br>As bound by potent spell of legendary lore.

What!  sleeps he now? — or school'd in tales of old,—</br>Chivalric scenes of terror and surprize,</br>Enthusiast strange!  do wildering fancies mould</br>His soul to frenzy, and delude his eyes?</br>Certes — some Sylph of more than mortal grace—</br>Nor less than angel's bright, her beauties beam,—</br>Arrests his view, — in deep, extatic dream:—</br>'Tis She — WERBURGHA fair — the Genius of the place.

"Range Thou Conjecture's labyrinth no more;</br>My favour to thy view" — she said, serene,</br>"Recals the fleeting pageant, — as of yore</br>It pass'd successive o'er this changeful scene.</br>Who trod this holy ground from age to age,</br>Since WULPHERE'S pious zeal the Fane design'd,</br>Stupendous effort of his princely mind,</br>Mark now; — and let the sight thy wondering thoughts engage."

The angelic Vision spoke; — and for a time</br>Varied the Mansion to his prospect lay;</br>Haunted it seem'd with Guests of other clime,</br>That stranger were than Fancy can portray!</br>Yet — for seclusion form'd, the tranquil dome</br>With many a hallowed sign its use confess'd,</br>By SAXON MAIDS — a sister-train, possess'd:—</br>The virgin-Saint they hail, — and hail their ancient home.

Each in her hand a flickering taper bore,</br>That shed faint lustre through the dim abode:</br>Sable, their robes descending swept the floor;</br>A snowy veil adown each bosom flow'd.</br>"Blest Guide!" the youth exclaim'd "oh!  deign to say</br>Who that bright Pair, conspicuous in the throng?"—</br>"Milburg and Mildred lov'd — of Woden sprung,"</br>Indulgent she replied — "my kindred vestals they."

"But lo!  they vanish: — turn thy curious gaze</br>On yon succeeding Group, whose aspect sage,</br>And habit strange, beseeming ancient days,</br>Denote them PASTORS of another age.</br>Less from the world apart; — less strict their vow:—</br>Observe the tonsure on each head imprest,</br>The beard prolix; the candid, flowing vest,</br>And hence their manly sex, — and priestly order know.

"Mark now a CHIEF immortal in renown:</br>What other hand that ponderous sword can wield?"</br>His brow encircled with a princely crown!</br>A gaunt Wolf threatens on his painted shield!</br>See at his call the ascetick train appear</br>Vacant (for so he will'd) the ample dome</br>They fill; — and wide through this our vestal home</br>Extend their ORDER'S sway:  and con their RULE austere.

"Earl HUGO! — thou (said she) hast heard that name,</br>To Cestria's sons in distant ages known:</br>For none more favour'd with the Norman came</br>To win by conquest sea-girt Britain's throne.</br>Nor mean the guerdon that his toils repaid</br>CESTRIA'S wide plains!  to hold by martial might,</br>As the proud Donor by imperial right</br>His regal state maintain'd, and Britain's sceptre sway'd.

"His strong hold once, that tow'r-flank'd Citadel</br>Conspicuous yet, mid old CAER-LEGION'S walls:</br>There he his state upheld, as legends tell,</br>With war-provided bands, in trophied halls;</br>And thence at will, his hardy vassals led</br>To drench with carnage dire the subject plain,—</br>Oft — as rapacious — o'er his fair domain,</br>Cambria her countless tribes from distant mountains spread.

"In happier times his haunt that fairy-ground</br>Where — pristine lustre beaming — DEVA strays,</br>And now, an ample Mansion turret-crown'd,</br>Rivals the grandeur of primeval days.</br>Bright emblems there by Herald's skill design'd,</br>Of ROLLO'S kindred line, the eschutcheon grace,</br>And Neustrian sires record — a martial race,</br>With Albion's gentlest dames in nuptial union join'd.

"See!  to these gates what subject Lords attend</br>Their Prince — so near to Royalty allied!</br>Hark!  paeans fill the Dome — and organs lend</br>Their powers, — to hail the pageantry of pride.</br>Reverse the scene — ah!  whither art thou fled</br>Vain dream of Greatness? — Lo!  with cares opprest,</br>Weak, old, dejected, — here he asks for rest,</br>His home the narrow cell; the pallet cold his bed.

"See of his state the Chieftain disarray'd;</br>Eas'd of its golden weight he bends his brow:</br>Shorn are the honours of his hoary head:</br>His lips pronounce the irrevocable vow.</br>Thy weeds — O BENEDICT!  his limbs invest:</br>His tottering step a pilgrim's staff sustains:—</br>Pleas'd, by the grant of lands and rich demesnes,</br>From Guilt's tormenting sting to free his troubled breast.

"But what these shadows of the illustrious dead,</br>Whose gorgeous state bespeaks their high degree?"</br>"These Cestria's EARLS, that in succession tread</br>Our courts, with prayer and choral minstrelsy:</br>ABBOTS, whose fronts the mitred honours grace,</br>Whose hands the crozier; — wont erewhile to hold</br>With Cestria's princely Chief and Barons bold</br>High conference, — and assert hereditary place!"

Thus — to her favour'd Minstrel's wondering gaze</br>Visions long past his sainted Guide recals,</br>And all the Minster's earliest pomp displays,</br>Its vaulted roofs, long aisles, and sculptur'd walls.</br>Now, from the Nave and Transept — towering high—</br>Leads to the REFECTORY'S distant site,—</br>Or PRIOR's devious home, or ABBOT'S, — bright</br>With rafters gilt, and sheen of solemn blazonry.

Nor deigns she not to tell, how once his state</br>The Abbey's mitred Ruler here maintain'd;</br>What trains his hall, — what menials fill'd his gate;</br>And at his board profuse what splendour reign'd:</br>And how those portals — hospitably wide—</br>Receiv'd each nobler stranger; — nor repell'd</br>The abject and the poor: — for sacred held,</br>Each Pilgrim's simpler claims a ready dole supplied.

And — how the Prior grave and courteous Guest</br>The social hour till evening dirge prolong;—</br>Then part in peace, and seek the haunts of rest;</br>And early wake, to join the Matin song.</br>For lo! — e'er Darkness take her drowsy flight,</br>Some hand hath trimm'd yon taper's smothering flame,</br>That through the DORMITORY'S length its gleam</br>Threw feeble, glimmering faint, with scarce distinguish'd light.

Each Cenobite erewhile his pallet there</br>In silent muse possess'd, or sleep profound</br>But hark!  a Bell athwart the misty air</br>Pours on the ear of Night its wonted sound.</br>No toilet him expects, — since girt his loin</br>In slumber, — nor abandon'd e'er his vest:</br>With downcast eye, and footstep half supprest,</br>Gliding through charnell'd ways, the choral band he joins.

For who — that on thy legend bends to pore</br>Sage BENEDICT!  and holy discipline</br>Kens not these nightly orisons? — nay more,</br>Prime, Third, Sixth, None, and Vespers, and Compline.</br>"Seven times the sceptred Prophet wont to raise</br>Through night's dark watches, and the cheerful day,</br>His voice to God: — as He — my children, Ye</br>Seven times shall pour the prayer, or chaunt the hymn of praise.

And Thou that would'st our holy warfare wage,</br>And win o'er self and sin the palm divine,</br>Know first — to teach is Wisdom's province sage,</br>To hear in silence — and obey — is thine.</br>To Thee — my Son — a father's counsels given</br>Shall prove as Jacob's ladder; whilom trod</br>By Angels — fleetest messengers of God,—</br>Who taught the Patriarch's gaze bright intercourse with heaven.

"Fear God:  be this Humility's first law.—</br>Let strong subjection curb thy recreant will.—</br>For God's love thy superiours hold in awe.—</br>Resign'd and patient, learn to suffer ill.—</br>From sage Confessor's ear, no secret guile</br>Of thought or act let faithless accents hide.—</br>Degraded and abas'd, thy penance bide</br>In meekness. — Deem thyself the vilest of the vile.

"Honour thy RULE; by this thy conduct square.</br>Speak seldom, — yet if question'd, mild reply.</br>The lightsome thought, the wanton laugh beware.</br>Season thy words with gentlest gravity.</br>With eyes that court the ground, but thoughts above;</br>Sitting or standing, if thou work or pray,</br>In choir and convent, garden, field, or way,</br>Let every varied act thy meek demeanour prove."

"And — was it thus" — the admiring youth replied,</br>"Each blest RECLUSE who bade the world adieu,</br>Victim no more of Envy, Ire, and Pride,—</br>Could calmly pay to God allegiance true!</br>Pow'rful though counsels are to sway the mind</br>To Virtue; — sweet the thoughts of doing well;</br>Yet Nature's froward children will rebel,</br>Their judgment prone to good, — their flesh to ill inclin'd."

His bright Conductress smil'd:  "Seest thou" said she,</br>"Yon MONK perverse, whose bosom's turbid flame</br>Lists to no soothing words of courtesy,</br>Nor grace can humble him, nor penance shame.</br>Yields he?  'tis but in semblance; — mark the scorn</br>Through hypocritic mask that lights his eye:—</br>Some fiend accurs'd impels his soul awry,</br>And bursts his labouring breast, by jarring passions torn.

"But will the wretch unmov'd, with hunger pine,</br>A mark of scorn to every Brother's view;</br>Nor crouch beneath the smarting discipline?</br>Then Heaven's own thunders shall his soul subdue.</br>Behold him prostrate on the sacred floor</br>Day after day — forlorn, unheeded, lie,</br>Till Pity can no more the boon deny:—</br>'Enough: — thy pardon seal'd — depart, and sin no more.'"

With meditative gaze, the Minstrel view'd</br>Each passing scene; and question'd much his mind;—</br>Fulfils Man Heaven's behests in solitude,</br>More dear to God, as more he shuns his kind?</br>Not so the SAVIOUR deem'd! — In every place</br>Where Man resorted, there his presence found</br>Its happiest sphere; diffusing widely round</br>Example's brightest light, and Virtue's loveliest grace.

More had he said: — but now his startled eye</br>Beholds new sights: — Processions, Pilgrimages,</br>Mix'd shows of "Holy Mummeries," — antic Joy,</br>And rabble-Rout; — and Interludes and Stages.</br>Strange sounds his ear assail of wild commotion,</br>As though by eddying storms of Limbo tost,</br>In the "Fool's Paradise" his thoughts were lost;—</br>And more his Fancy dreams of Riot than Devotion.

But soon, a FORM MAJESTIC sprang to view</br>Of frowning mien; — a diadem he wore:—</br>"Depart," he sternly said, "licentious crew,</br>And dare profane these hallow'd walls no more."</br>Instant a Seraph, rob'd in purest light,</br>Shot like a falling star, athwart the shade:</br>'Twas heavenly TRUTH! — She came, resplendent Maid,</br>To dissipate the gloom of intellectual night.

"Blest be the dawn of this auspicious day,"</br>The Virgin cried: — "Delusion!  cease thy reign:</br>Error!  no longer cloud the mental ray:</br>Fell Bigotry!  resign thy torch and chain.</br>Here — let Religion — more serenely bright</br>From mists emerging — with full splendour shine;</br>And Learning haste to build her favourite shrine."</br>The Vision spake, — and straight evanish'd from his sight.</br>
